fields.description:
Attachments cannot be stored on the filesystem in a Clustered instance.
But in "Attachment Storage", the "Locally in Confluence Home Directory" option is still available.
Hence, users attempting to migrate attachments from the DB or WebDav to the filesystem, experience the following error:
{noformat}

fields.description:
A few users have reported to have lost all admin rights for a Space and not able to perform any "Administrative" tasks on this Space such as adding or removing users and groups. For every such action, they receive the error "You are not allowed to remove all the Administration Permissions for this space." This problem was mostly observed while performing a Space import/export or a site restore. For some reason, the Space lost all "admin" rights during this task.

The workaround to this problem, at the moment is to assign permissions manually through the database, as there is no "System Administrator" or "Super User" who can assign Space Level permissions through a UI, in situations such as these.

The following steps are recommended for assigning space permissions manually:
Please ensure that you have a complete backup of your <Confluence-Home> AND your database before attempting the following steps:

1) You would first be required to locate the Space Key corresponding to your space which can be located by going to the "Browse Space" section of this space and refer to the URL displayed at the top of the page. It should be similar to:

http://localhost:8080/pages/listpages-dirview.action?key=<Your Space key>

2) Connect to your database and run the following query on the SPACES table:
{noformat}
SELECT SPACEID FROM SPACES WHERE SPACEKEY = '<Your Space key from Step 1>'
{noformat}
This query will give you the SPACEID for the Space for which the "admin" rights have been lost.
3) Run the following query on your SPACEPERMISSIONS table:
{noformat}
INSERT INTO SPACEPERMISSIONS 
(PERMID,SPACEID,PERMTYPE,PERMUSERNAME,CREATOR,CREATIONDATE,LASTMODIFIER,LASTMODDATE) VALUES 
(<PERMID relative to your table>,
<SpaceID from the previous query>,
<'One of the Permissions from the list below'>,
<'Username to whom the permission has to be assigned'>,
<'Username who created the Space'>,
<'Creation Date'>,
<'Username who last modified this Space'>,
<'Last modified Date'>)
{noformat}
The list of available Space permissions:
VIEW
COMMENT
EDITSPACE
SETSPACEPERMISSIONS
REMOVEPAGE
REMOVECOMMENT
CREATEATTACHMENT
REMOVEATTACHMENT
EDITBLOG
EXPORTPAGE
EXPORTSPACE
REMOVEMAIL
SETPAGEPERMISSIONS

Refresh your database after editing this table to ensure the new values have been updated correctly and then revisit your Space and check whether the new permissions are reflected in the "Browse Space->Permissions" page.
fields.summary: Space is left with no "admin" and users being locked-out of administering a space

fields.description:
In previous confluence versions log4j would default to use the FileAppender, in recent 2.6 versions this has been set to the ConsoleAppender.

According to comments in the log4j.properties file, the ConsoleAppender (which is used during development) should automatically be replaced with the FileAppender for deployment use.

The logging defaults have changed in 2.7 (http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONF-6582) but 2.6 should still be using the FileAppender.  It looks like the changes to the build process introduced for 2.6, did not migrate this log4j step correctly.
fields.summary: Confluence 2.6 Default Log Settings are Incorrect

The word "webserver" was changed to "web server" on 3 of the lines, but it is only marked up in 2 spots (instead of 6, and each of those 2 spots are on different lines).

fields.description: Browse your space and click the Attachements Tab. Fill in the "Filter by File Extension" box and click Go. The filtering works (although it's case-sensitive), but the pagination is messed up. See the screenshots for examples. The results for page 2 and page 4 should be on the second page of results. It looks as though the attachment list is just hiding entries that don't have the extension you've chosen. It should be recalculating the results and shortening the list.
fields.summary: Pagination on Attachments tab does not reflect filtered results

fields.description:
The Crowd libraries in Confluence need updating to get around an error found with XFire http://jira.codehaus.org/browse/XFIRE-888

This should mean the following for Confluence's parent pom.

{code:xml}
<dependency>
  <groupId>woodstox</groupId>
  <artifactId>wstx-asl</artifactId>
  <version>3.2.0</version>
  <scope>runtime</scope>
</dependency>
<dependency>
   <groupId>org.codehaus.xfire</groupId>
   <artifactId>xfire-all</artifactId>
  <version>1.2.6</version>
  <scope>runtime</scope>
</dependency>
{code}
fields.summary: Move the XFire dependency for Crowd from 1.2.1 to 1.2.6

fields.description: Confluence since 2.6.x doesn't ship the source of its core plugins as part of the source distribution. This was done like so as part of the plan to open source those plugins. This should be done ASAP.
fields.summary: Open source Confluence system and bundled plugins

Managing your Repositories - wysiwygcontent =

When adding or managing a Perforce repository, you can:

  • Define repository details, as described below.
  • Set FishEye's repository options .
  • Set up a Perforce client .

Perforce Repository Details

Name A name for this repository. The name may contain alphanumeric, underscore, '-' or '.' characters. Use 'perforce' if you can't think of a better name.
Description A short description of this repository.
Perforce Host The name of the server which provides the Perforce repository.
Port The port the server is listening on. This field is optional. FishEye will default to the standard Perforce port (1666) if you do not specify a value here.
Path The path within the Perforce depot that you wish to have FishEye index. You would normally put the depot path here, e.g. //depot/ but you may also use a more specific path to restrict FishEye to a subset of the depot.
Block Size Controls how many changelists FishEye will fetch from the depot in one batch. Larger values can reduce the time it takes for FishEye to scan your repository for changes, but use more memory. The default is 400.
Filelog limit FishEye uses the P4 filelog command to gather information about the files in changesets. The list of files generated can be very large. Setting a limit here will cause FishEye to batch up filelog operations into groups. This is useful with some versions of the Perforce client which may have trouble with large output. In general you should only set this field if you have a 2005 client or earlier. Lower values will degrade scanning performance.
P4 Operation Timeout Sets the timeout value that FishEye imposes on P4 operations. Operations which exceed this value are terminated. The default for most operations is 10 minutes.
Throttle connections-per-sec If set, this allows FishEye to throttle how many connections it makes per second to the Perforce server. The default is blank (do not throttle). You may enter fractional values such as 2.5.
Charset The character set used to interpret and display text files.
Unicode Server This field indicates whether the Perforce Server is running in internationalised mode.
Case Sensitive This field indicates whether the Perforce Server metadata is case sensitive. You should set this to 'false' for servers running on Windows platforms.
Username/Password The credentials to use if your repository requires authentication.
Enable immediately Controls whether FishEye will immediately enable this repository, which starts the initial scan. If you wish to do some further configuration before the scan starts, then select 'No'. You can enable a repository later from the Repository List.

fields.description:
With clients setting up their application server on one continent and their database server on another continent, it is no surprise if their performance is bad.

We should do some really simple queries (using JDBC, making sure no results can get caches locally) and display the latency in the system information page. Anything above a certain threshold could be marked red.
fields.summary: Check for database latency and display it in system information page

fields.description:
We have a space with no space admin.  When I try and make a user and admin or make a group an admin, I get the following error:

The following error(s) occurred: 

You are not allowed to remove all the Administration Permissions for this space. 

When I talked to support on the phone, they mentioned that it was probably a database issue, but told me not to edit the database directly.  I'm trying to figure out how to edit the database indirectly to solve this problem.  Will an export/import of the space fix the issue?  I can't upload the zip of the space because the content is highly confidential.
fields.summary: One of our spaces does not have a space admin.  This prevents us from modifying any of the users/groups in that space.

fields.description:
My suggestion is simply to be able to define the tasks already in typing the makro. (I.e {dynamictasklist:Task42status:|Order accepted|Developer|Designer|Customer|}  )
I don't know how most people use the dynamic task list, but this would enable me to use the dynamics of this instead of having to edit the entire page. Today I use a big table combined with (x) and (/) to view and update status on the tasks my project is working on. When the the table gets bigger it is not easy to navigate the code to change status. The dynamics of the dynamic task list would enable people to update status a lot faster, and would make the confluence wiki an even more powerful tool for projects. 
I believe that this would to a certain degree also help CONF-3469 "Renaming a dynamic task list loses all tasks" and CONF-3390 "There's no option to rename/edit a task, so if you make a mistake you have to delete the task and re-enter it from scratch." Because the tasks are defined in the code, and not depending on a specific ID.

A bit more complex request is the possibility to address this task list from another page. Any task might have its own page, but there may also be need for an overview page. It would be great if this could be handled automatically by a linked reference (i.e {dynamictasklist:[Task42]Task42status:Order accepted|Developer|Designer|Customer|} )

Basically this would make it easier for me and our project both to implement task lists, and by being able to use them it will also be easier to update information.
fields.summary: Dynamictasklist improvement. Predefined tasks.

fields.description: Users are looking for more options as compared to the features and capability available in the Word processor.
fields.summary: Improve rich text editor to be more Word processor like

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-9782].
  {panel}

Some organisations require the option to switch all mission-critical applications to an offsite backup in the event that the primary instance goes down. Please document the basics of setting this up:

1. Install Confluence to a backup server using a development key that is not running
2. Setup a load balancer front end that can test if Confluence is responsive on the primary and backup servers
3. Setup a database backup system that transfers the database contents to the backup server database, eg nightly or hourly
4. Setup a script so that the load balancer will start the backup instance, stop the periodic database transfers and redirect requests in the event that the primary goes down

If there's a better method then we should document that instead.
fields.summary: Document maintaining an offsite backup instance for failover

fields.description:
The maven artifacts for confluence plugins are missing out of date or wrong.  E.g. there is a plugin archetype:

mvn archetype:create     -DarchetypeGroupId=com.atlassian.maven.archetypes     -DarchetypeArtifactId=confluence-plugin-archetype     -DarchetypeVersion=2.1     -DremoteRepositories=http://repository.atlassian.com/maven2/     -DgroupId=com.example.confluence.plugin     -DartifactId=example-plugin

But the resulting project has a parent that is missing from any repository defined in the pom.

There is also a potential surrogate parent at 

        <groupId>com.atlassian.confluence</groupId>
        <artifactId>confluence-plugin-support</artifactId>
        <version>2.2.9-1</version>

in http://svn.atlassian.com/svn/public/contrib/repository/maven2/ (which is named as a repository location in the archetype project).  But that has a dependency on an old confluence (2.4.5) which isn't in any repo (neither is any other version - http://repository.atlassian.com/maven2 has nothing under com/atlassian/confluence.

It seems like it shouldn't be realy hard to sort this out - just one archetype with its dependencies.
fields.summary: Confluence Maven artifacts are missing from repository.atlassian.com/maven2/com/atlassian/confluence/

fields.description:
The new default dashboard REMOVES The "+" and "-" icons, which were useful to  "show more recent changes" etc...while introducing "personalization icons" that eat up lots of space with limited utility.

From our groups perspective, you have eliminated a valuable function.  Can you tell me how the development team suggests that users monitor recent changes?  We became accustomed to those using those buttons to catch up on changes, which sometimes required scanning dozens of recent changes made across multiple spaces.  If you eliminated this use case from the dashboard, what is the "workaround" we should use to review recent changes?

fields.description:
The other day, I renamed a page within our devnet, and I found that all links to that page with a keyspace were broken because the links were not updated. Links with no keyspace are updated correctly.

You can reproduce this rather easily:
- Create a page and add two links to it, say [test] and [space:test]
- Create a page called test
- Rename the page called test (say, into test2)
- On the first page, the link without keyspace ([test]) will point to the renamed page, while the other link (with the keyspace, [space:test]) will be broken.
fields.summary: Links with keyspace broken on page renaming

fields.description:
I just noticed that Confluence is accidentally including two versions of JTA dependencies. If you look in (confluence-std-2.6.0)/confluence/WEB-INF/lib/ there are:

-rw-r--r--     8809 Aug 16 03:13 jta-1.0.1.jar
-rw-r--r--     8382 Aug 16 03:10 jta-1.0.1B.jar

In addition there are dependencies where the newer version of the jar could likely be used instead of the older version like:

-rw-r--r--   247021 Aug 16 03:13 jtidy-r8-20050104.jar
-rw-r--r--   246990 Aug 16 03:09 jtidy-r8-21122004.jar

And (although this one looks a little scarier since it decreased in size):

-rw-r--r--   63992 Aug 16 03:07 mockobjects-j1.3-j2ee1.3-0.07.jar
-rw-r--r--   57598 Aug 16 03:07 mockobjects-jdk1.3-j2ee1.2-0.09.jar

And ofbcore which according to a different ticket isn't even being used:

-rw-r--r--   236334 Aug 16 03:17 ofbcore-entity-2.1.1-atlassian-21Mar06.jar
-rw-r--r--   150255 Aug 16 03:10 ofbcore-ofbcore-share-2.1.1.jar

Duplicate jars:

-rw-r--r--     6672 Aug 16 03:13 pell-multipart-2.1.5.jar
-rw-r--r--     6672 Aug 16 03:09 pell-multipart.jar

And mixtures of duplicate and different versions like:

-rw-r--r--     12318 Aug 16 03:13 alt-0.07-j1.3-j2ee1.3.jar
-rw-r--r--     8116 Aug 16 03:11 alt-0.07-jdk1.3.jar
-rw-r--r--     8116 Aug 16 03:08 alt-jdk1.3-0.07.jar

Since there was also a dependency issue in 2.5.7, it would seem as if Atlassian might want to implement some sort of process in which someone reviews the list of dependencies included with all of the developers to make sure it is sane before releasing a final build.

Dependencies of a dependency can be excluded in a Maven 2 pom by using the exclusions element, for example:

            <dependency>
                <groupId>commons-logging</groupId>
                <artifactId>commons-logging</artifactId>
                <version>1.1</version>
                <exclusions>
                    <exclusion>
                        <groupId>log4j</groupId>
                        <artifactId>log4j</artifactId>
                    </exclusion>
                    <exclusion>
                        <groupId>logkit</groupId>
                        <artifactId>logkit</artifactId>
                    </exclusion>
                    <exclusion>
                        <groupId>avalon-framework</groupId>
                        <artifactId>avalon-framework</artifactId>
                    </exclusion>
                    <exclusion>
                        <groupId>javax.servlet</groupId>
                        <artifactId>servlet-api</artifactId>
                    </exclusion>
                </exclusions>
            </dependency>

I know that if you have two different versions of dependencies each built against some other version of the same dependency, that it is tricky to remove one or the other and in some cases perhaps it would make sense to have two different versions of the same jar and hope that the JVM can figure it all out. However, when you see duplicate dependencies in the list, to me that just looks a little sloppy.

Hope this helps.

fields.description:
"View" permissions for Groups and Individual Users is being lost on Space-level.
The problem has been reproduced with "Local" AND "LDAP" Groups on "Groups" level and only with "LDAP" users on Individual-Users level.
The problem is related to case-sensitivity with user and group names.

Steps for reproducing this problem are:

1) Create a username and group using *uppercase* characters in LDAP and locally in Confluence
2) Go to "Browse Space->Advanced->Space Permissions" 
3) Go to "Individual Users" section and *type* the name of this user in *lowercase* and click on "Add". Please do not use the "User-Picker" in this step.
4) Confluence will correctly pick up the user and display the username in *uppercase*, as the user was originally created.
5) Select *all* available permissions for this space for this user and click on "Save All"
6) Notice that the "View" permission is *not checked* after saving.
7) Edit the permissions again by going to "Edit Permissions" and notice that the "View" permission is now *checked*.
8) Remove *all* available permissions for this user and click on "Save All"
9) Notice now that *only View* permission is *checked* and all others are *unchecked*
10) This user can now not be removed from the "Individual Users" permissions section as the "View" permissions keep toggling.
11) Repeat the above steps for "Groups", with a group name in *uppercase*. 

Tested with "Classic" and "Default" themes.

Cannot reproduce on Confluence v2.5.7
fields.summary: Group and individual users "View" permissions lost on Space-level due to case-sensitivity.

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
1. Go to a space which has permissions assigned only to groups.
2. Grant all permissions to an individual user (e.g. yourself), and grant 'View' permission to 'Anonymous'. Save your changes.
3. Remove all permissions from the individual user. Save your changes.
4. The 'View' permission for 'Anonymous' disappears.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-9742].
  {panel}

In very large organization, some labels are used for special meanings. For example:
'article-for-review'
'delete-me'
'featured-article'
'specification-document'
'approved'
'obsolete'

While every effort is made to make things wide open, and deal with 'mistakes' through 'education' rather than control, in many cases the COST in time and resources to educate people on the proper use of high-impact labels outweighs the benefit.  While most labels can and should remain open, significant efficiencies and time savings can be achieved by limiting the use of certain labels to certain groups. For example:

If the 'delete-me' label above was linked to an automated review and deletion process, it could be limited to only be used by people in the 'moderators' group. Anyone could use a 'review-for-deletion' label, but not the specific 'delete-me' label.

Likewise, if the 'approved' label was restricted to the people that have the approval authority for a given process or expenditure, then a separate approval process would not be needed outside of confluence: the approved label could be used with certainty.

Further, if labels like 'featured-article' was linked to articles that were shown on the top-level page of a large organization, and 'specification-document' label was used as a 'document class' with a special meaning that only a fraction of the organization really understood, and the use of these were limited to a group called "Users-that-have-completed-confluence-training" or "users-in-the-specification-group", then education on certain high-impact topics could be achieved proactively rather than retroactively.
fields.summary: Create a permission system to restrict add or remove label actions for individual labels

fields.description:
The getChildren function should return a list of all the pages in a space that have no parent if it is passed a parentId of zero or -1 or some other documented magic number.

I am having trouble using getPages function with XML-RPC because my space is too large.  There are several thousand pages in the space.  Rather that getting all the page summaries at once, I would like to be able get them in chunks by using the getChildren function to walk through the space hierarchy.  However, there does not appear to be any documented API function which will return a list of all the root pages in the space (i.e. pages with no parent).
fields.summary: getChildren should return pages with no parent if parentId is zero

fields.description:
Hi,

In a confluence space, I have a page which is restricted by certain group(say. abc).
Now the case is that on that space we have permission to two groups 'admin' group and 'abc' group(my which page has been restricted).   'admin' group have all the permissions including that space admin.

Now the issue is that 'admin' group member can go to 'Space admin section --> Restricted pages , in this section he is  able to view the page which is restricted by abc group and also remove that permission from the page.

This should not be possible: as admin member is not a member of 'abc' (restricted group) so the page will not viewable under 'Restricted pages' section. OR if viewable then he will not be able to remove the permission for that page, as he is not member of that restricted group.

Regards,
- Vishal

fields.summary: Security Issue: XSS in wiki exception error page

fields.description:
On pages using the {children} tags with a depth of anything greater than 1, if there are a large number of pages with explicit permissions set, the page in question can take minutes to load. 

Removing the {children} tag solves the issue. This page loaded in a reasonable amount of time under Confluence 2.5.

This is a production issue for approximately 200 users, in multiple spaces.

fields.summary: Permissions checking on {children} tags consuming large amounts of CPU time

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-9702].
  {panel}

Update Confluence SOAP API to be at least as current as XML-RPC API, add more service methods for General Admin, Space Admin, Page/Content Admin, User/Group Admin, and implement processes/policies to keep it up to speed as Confluence develops.

There are so many more things that people could be doing with Confluence if the Remote APIs were bulked up.

And doesn't have to be that hard for people to keep up-to-date with the API as it changes. Anyone using Maven 2 in any project could use the org.codehaus.mojo axistools-maven-plugin to very easily and automatically generate SOAP client code by just including the following plugin in their project and putting wsdl into a wsdl directory:

            <!-- target = axistools:wsdl2java -->
            <plugin>
                <groupId>org.codehaus.mojo</groupId>
                <artifactId>axistools-maven-plugin</artifactId>
                <configuration>
                    <sourceDirectory>wsdl</sourceDirectory>
                    <packageSpace>csum.confluence.permissionmgmt.soap</packageSpace>
                    <testCases>false</testCases>
                    <serverSide>false</serverSide>
                    <subPackageByFileName>true</subPackageByFileName>
                </configuration>
                <executions>
                    <execution>
                        <goals>
                            <goal>wsdl2java</goal>
                        </goals>
                    </execution>
                </executions>
            </plugin>

fields.description:
The "TinyMCE" plugin is not rendered correctly in Confluence v2.6.0 and the "Wiki-Markup" and "Preview" buttons are non-functional.

The issue has been reported on Mozilla1.7, Firefox2.07 and IE7 browsers on Sun Java Desktop System, Linux and Vista.
Customers have reported that clearing the browser cache and restarting Confluence has also not helped in resolving this problem.

A workaround posted by one of the Customers to this problem was to reinstall the TinyMCE plugin.

Please refer to the attached screenshot for more details regarding the nature of the problem.
fields.summary: TinyMCE editor window does not render properly and leavs the Wiki-Markup and Preview tabs non-functional
